title: Mutare Sports Club
text:
Mutare Sports Club is a <a href="cricket">cricket</a> ground in <a href="Mutare">Mutare</a>, <a href="Manicaland%20Province">Manicaland Province</a>, Zimbabwe. It is located just to the south-east of the city centre, next to Main Park.
It has been the home ground of the <a href="Mountaineers%20cricket%20team">Mountaineers</a>, one of Zimbabwe's <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> franchises, since they were formed in 2009. Prior to the reorganisation of Zimbabwean cricket, it was the home ground of the <a href="Manicaland%20cricket%20team">Manicaland</a> team. The ground was originally called the Umtali Sports Club, before Umtali was renamed as Mutare in 1982.
The first <a href="List%20A%20cricket">List A cricket</a> match at the ground took place in March 1984, when <a href="Zimbabwe%20national%20cricket%20team">Zimbabwe</a> played the touring Young India team. The first <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class</a> match took place in March 2000 when Manicaland played <a href="Mashonaland%20cricket%20team">Mashonaland</a> in the <a href="Logan%20Cup">Logan Cup</a>. The ground and its facilities for players and spectators were upgraded in 2010.
Mutare Sports Club was the scene of a key incident in Indian cricket's <a href="Chappell%E2%80%93Ganguly%20controversy">Chappell–Ganguly controversy</a>, when during a warm-up match at the ground on <a href="Indian%20cricket%20team%20in%20Zimbabwe%20in%202005">India's 2005 tour of Zimbabwe</a>, coach <a href="Greg%20Chappell">Greg Chappell</a> suggested captain <a href="Sourav%20Ganguly">Sourav Ganguly</a> should stand down from the team.
Mutare Sports Club is also the home ground of the Mutare Sports Club <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> team, who play in the Harare Provincial Rugby League.
